III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 9/20/24, youth was taken to the hospital to be evaluated. He
had to be shackled and handcuffed during transport. Youth
escaped the shackles at the hospital and attempted to leave.
Hospital security detained that you and placed him into cuffs.
Youth was thrown against the wall 3 times by security and facility
staff. Youth hit their head against the wall when they were thrown
against the wall. Youth had red marks on the wrist because the
handcuffs were on tightly.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 24, 2024. Director reported Youth A had a court
hearing on Friday, September 20, 2024, via phone. Youth A got
upset during the hearing and threw the phone. Due to this
behavior, Foster Care Worker requested he go to the hospital for
a mental health evaluation. She reported that Staff 1 and Staff 2
had taken Youth A to the hospital. Director reported she was
notified Youth A had gotten out of his handcuffs and attempted to
run away from the hospital. Due to this behavior, hospital security
was contacted and assisted in getting the handcuffs back on
Youth A because his behaviors were escalating at the hospital.
Director reported Youth A reported staff from the facility and the
hospital threw him against the wall at least three times and he hit
his head when he was thrown. Youth A also reported red marks
on his wrist because security at the hospital put the handcuffs on
too tight.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 25, 2024. Youth A reported on Friday, September 20,
2024, he went to the hospital because he was upset after his court
hearing. He reported while at the hospital he was able to talk with
a social worker and when the hospital was about to discharge him,
2

he became upset. Youth A explained he did not want to come
back to the facility, so he behaviorally acted out. He reported he
was able to slide his hands out of the handcuffs and was going to
attempt to run away. Youth A reported that Staff 2 and security at
the hospital stopped him by throwing him up against the wall three
times. He reported security was the one to put the handcuffs back
on him as he was trying to punch and shove people away. Youth
A reported his only injury was on his wrists because security put
his handcuffs on too tight which caused red marks. Throughout
the interview, Youth A continued to state he needed to be moved
out of the facility because he does not like to be locked up and
deserves to be in a foster home. He reported that he likes going to
the hospital because he gets away from the facility and other
youth, to eat better food, and watch TV.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 24, 2024. Staff 1 reported she took Youth A to the
hospital with Staff 2 for a mental health evaluation. She reported
upon arrival at the hospital, Youth A remained in his handcuffs
which is their protocol. Staff 1 reported Youth A talked with the
hospital staff and after they left, he continued to play with his
handcuffs. She reported Youth A was able to get his hands out of
the handcuffs. Youth A then started to have escalating behaviors
and attempted to run out of the room. Staff 1 reported hospital
security came into the room to assist with Youth A’s behaviors and
handcuff Youth A. She reported Staff 2 intervened with hospital
security and was able to hold Youth A’s arms as they were trained
to get him into handcuffs. She reported Youth A was never thrown
up against the wall when he was trying to get re-cuffed, he
continued to try to headbang on the wall and the staff. Staff 1
reported she witnessed hospital security be the ones to put on the
handcuffs on Youth A’s wrist. She reported Youth A calmed down
and was cleared to go back to the facility. Staff 1 reported she had
no concerns with the way the situation was handled.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 25, 2024. Staff 2 reported he brought Youth A to the
hospital with Staff 1 on September 20, 2024, per the request of
Director. He reported that everything went fine at the hospital and
Youth A was evaluated by the medical staff. Staff 2 reported once
Youth A found out he was going to be discharged back to the
facility, he began to play with the handcuffs on his wrist. He
reported Youth A to wiggle his hand out of the cuffs and started
yelling that he was not returning. Staff 2 reported he asked for
hospital security to come assist as Youth A was also attempting to
leave the hospital room. He reported Youth A kept trying to swing
3

at security with his wrists. Staff 2 reported he assisted with
security to get Youth A’s hands to be able to be re-cuffed. He
reported Youth A was never thrown up against the wall and stated
that Youth A kept attempting to head-butt. Staff 2 reported security
at the hospital was able to put the handcuffs back on Youth A. He
reported there was never any physical abuse that occurred to
Youth A. Staff 2 reported when they got back to the facility after a
bit of time had passed, he went to process with Youth A. He
reported Youth A was calm and noted that he was just acting out
because he did not want to be locked up at the facility. Staff 2
reported the only complaint Youth A had was that his wrist hurt
because the hospital security put the handcuffs on too tight and
caused a red mark.
Hospital Social Worker was interviewed via phone on
September 23, 2024. Hospital Social Worker reported she was
unaware of any incidents involving Youth A on September 20,
2024. She reported there was also no documentation noting any
concerns of abuse at the hospital. Hospital Social Worker reported
if there were any concerns or any witness of abuse at the hospital
this would have been documented and called into centralized
intake. She reported she would pass this consultants information
on to the security supervisor at the hospital.
Documentation Reviewed:
- Email with Foster Care Worker dated September 23,
2024- Foster Care Worker is the primary worker for Youth
A. She reported Youth A had court prior to his behaviors
escalating at the facility on September 20, 2024. Foster
Care worker stated Youth A refused to speak with her on
the phone and threw things around in the meeting office.
She stated due to his escalating behaviors while she was
on the phone with him, she requested the facility take him
to the hospital for a psychological evaluation.
- Facility Incident Report Dated September 20, 2024-This
incident reported was consistent with Staff 1’s interview.
- Facility’s Youth Discipline and Behavior Modification Policy-
This policy notes the facility prohibits cruel and unusual
punishment including any type of physical discipline.
- Staff 1’s Personnel File- There was one disciplinary action in
Staff 1’s file. The disciplinary action was from November 2023
due to getting into a verbal altercation with another staff in front
of youth. She was provided a written reprimand and completed a
corrective action plan successfully in January 2024. Staff 1
completed the required trainings. She completed MANDT Verbal
De-Escalation training on August 29, 2024, MANDT Physical
4

Skills on August 30, 2024, and Child Management
Technique/Discipline Techniques on May 23, 2024.
- Staff 2’s Personnel File- There was no disciplinary record and
Staff 2 completed the required trainings. He completed Crisis
Intervention- Verbal De-escalation Training on February 15,
2024, MANDT Verbal De-Escalation training on September 16,
2024, and MANDT Physical Skills on August 30, 2024
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as Staff 1 and Staff 2 denied
Youth A getting thrown against the wall, and Hospital Social
Worker indicated no concerns of abuse or neglect. There were no
videos and no marks on Youth A following the incident.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code Sufficiency of staff.
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4126
Section (1) The licensee shall have a sufficient number of administrative,
Description supervisory, social service, direct care, and other staff on duty to
perform the prescribed functions required by these administrative
rules and in the agency's program statement and to provide for the
continual needs, protection, and supervision of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth is brought to the hospital for mental health concerns
repeatedly and there are concerns that staff at the facility are
unable to keep the youth safe.
Investigation Interviews:
Director was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 25, 2024. Director reported Youth A is offered
individual and group therapy. She reported Foster Care Worker
and the administration of her team have requested the facility to
bring Youth A to the hospital with any behavioral or mental health
concerns. Director reported Youth A has treated this as a break to
get out of the facility to go to the hospital. She reported Youth A
has stated to staff numerous times that he wants to go to the
hospital today to get a break or because they are serving good
food at the hospital. Director reported the practice at the facility is
if a youth were a danger to themselves, they would go on suicide
precautions where they would have their room cleared out and
staff sitting outside of their room for supervision. She reported that
their on-call psychiatrist would then come in to assess the youth.
Director reported due to the request of Youth A’s foster care team
they brought him to the hospital instead. She reported there are
weekly meetings happening about Youth A’s treatment and plan
with his foster care team.
5

Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 25, 2024. Youth A reported he hates living at the
facility because he does not like to be locked up and does not like
the other youth at the facility. He reported he does not like the
programming and wants to be in a foster home. Youth A reported
that he does get individual therapy weekly, monthly medication
reviews with a psychiatrist, and is offered group therapy. He
reported he does not feel like therapy is helping him and does not
want to partake in the group because of the other youth. Youth A
reported it is part of his plan with Foster Care Worker that if he
has any behaviors where he is hurting anyone or himself, he
needs to go to the hospital. He reported that he likes going to the
hospital because he gets away from the facility and other youth, to
eat better food, and watch TV. Youth A reported he needs to get
out of a locked facility and into a foster home. He reported there
are some good staff at the facility that he can talk to. Youth A
reported he does get mad at staff because they are always
watching him and redirecting his behaviors.
Therapist was interviewed face to face at the facility on
September 25, 2024. Therapist reported she has been working
with Youth A since he arrived at the facility which was at the end
of June 2024. She reported Youth A gets weekly individual
therapy and group therapy with his peers. Therapist reported
Youth A also meets monthly with the facility’s psychiatrist. She
reported she was going to begin family therapy with his extended
family but that has fallen through. Youth A did make it through the
orientation part of their programming but once there was more
accountability being held on his actions, his behaviors started to
show. Therapist reported Youth A is very behavioral and is very
lucid about the actions he takes. She reported Youth A needs a
secure setting and is currently having difficulty with being held
accountable by staff. Therapist reported one part of their
programming involves peers holding peers accountable which
Youth A does not do well with. She reported she has been
involved in meetings with Foster Care Worker and her
management stating Youth A needs to go to the hospital for a
mental health evaluation when he is having behaviors towards
others or himself. Therapist reported Youth A uses this as a way
to get out of the facility and be in control of his environment. She
reported Youth A will tell staff on the unit that he wants to go to the
hospital today and staff try to process with him about his choices.
Therapist reported Youth A then within a half hour will show
behaviors to the point they need to take him to the hospital. She
reported he has never been authorized for inpatient because he
6

will calm down once he gets what he wants. Therapist reported
they are constantly on calls with Youth A’s care team about his
case plan and behaviors. She reported she does not have
concerns with the staff level of supervision of Youth A.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone on September
25, 2024. Foster Care Worker reported she has been working with
Youth A for several years and reported he does not do well with
being held accountable. She reported Youth A struggles because
he does not want to be in a secure facility and believes that if he
acts out, he will get kicked out of the facility. Foster Care Worker
reported her leadership has requested the facility bring Youth A to
the hospital any time he struggles with behavior or shows mental
health concerns. She reported Youth A is appropriate for the
facility, but he is not engaging in individual and group therapy.
Foster Care Worker reported she is not concerned about his
safety at the facility and believes the staff are doing the best they
can. She reported she is having weekly meetings with the facility
about support for Youth A. Foster Care Worker confirmed Youth A
is a dual ward meaning that he has delinquency charges on him
and has been court order into to this facility.
Documents Reviewed:
- Facility Program Statement- The facility specializes in
serving delinquent youth in a treatment program that
provides long-term therapeutic programs which includes
delinquent youth with severe emotional disturbances. They
offer group therapy, rational behavioral training, individual
counseling, life skills and social skills training, peer group
process, mentoring and advocacy, peer mentioning, family
services, educational services, and medical services. The
facility has two consulting psychiatrist that provide services
6 hours a week to the youth. These psychiatrists are also
available 24 hours a day for emergencies.
- Youth A’s File- Youth A has been receiving appropriate
medical care and services offered by the facility. Youth A’s
is provided weekly individual counseling, monthly onsite
psychiatry appointments, group therapy, and has
appropriate goals listed within his treatment plan.
Analysis The facility is in compliance with providing Youth A all of the
required treatment. The facility is following the treatment plan put
into place with Foster Care Worker when it comes to bringing
Youth A to the hospital for evaluations.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
